title: Quiz 23: Renal & Urology
topicName: NCK Paper 1 Anatomy and Physiology Questions

questions.question: A patient presents with flank pain, hematuria, and a palpable mass in the abdomen. Imaging reveals a solid renal mass with calcifications. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.explanation: The classic triad of Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC) is Flank Pain + Hematuria + Palpable Mass. Although the full triad appears in only a minority of cases, it is the classic textbook presentation.
questions.hint: Think of the 'Classic Triad' for kidney cancer.

richContent.content:
RCC Classic Triad:
  • Hematuria (most common)
  • Flank Pain
  • Palpable Abdominal Mass

questions.question: A patient with a history of nephrolithiasis presents with sudden-onset severe colicky flank pain radiating to the groin. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the costovertebral angle and hematuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.text: Renal colic due to ureteral calculus

questions.explanation: Renal colic is characterized by sudden, severe, fluctuating pain radiating from the flank to the groin, typically caused by the passage of a kidney stone.
questions.hint: Pain that moves from the back down to the groin, often described as worse than childbirth.

questions.question: A patient with chronic kidney disease presents with progressively worsening anemia and elevated serum phosphate levels. Which medication is commonly prescribed to reduce serum phosphate levels in patients with chronic kidney disease?
questions.explanation: Sevelamer is a phosphate binder taken with meals to prevent the absorption of dietary phosphate.
questions.hint: A medication that binds phosphate in the gut.

questions.question: A patient presents with urinary frequency, urgency, dysuria, and suprapubic pain. Urinalysis reveals pyuria and bacteriuria. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.explanation: These are the classic signs of cystitis (lower UTI): frequency, urgency, painful urination, and suprapubic pain.
questions.hint: The most common bacterial infection of the bladder.

questions.question: A patient with diabetes mellitus presents with polyuria, polydipsia, nocturia, and fatigue. Laboratory findings reveal hyperglycemia, glycosuria, and ketonuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The presence of ketones (ketonuria) distinguishes DKA from other hyperglycemic states like HHS.
questions.hint: The presence of 'ketones' in the urine is the key differentiator.

richContent.content:
FeatureDKAHHS
KetonesPositiveNegative/Trace
pHAcidic (<7.3)Normal (>7.3)

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic kidney disease presents with pruritus, pale skin, and easy bruising. Laboratory findings reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.explanation: Uremia causes qualitative platelet defects (dysfunction), leading to increased bleeding time and easy bruising despite normal or slightly low platelet counts.
questions.hint: High urea levels interfere with how platelets stick together.

questions.question: A patient presents with sudden-onset severe scrotal pain, swelling, and erythema. Physical examination reveals a tender, swollen, and high-riding testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A high-riding testicle, loss of cremasteric reflex, and sudden severe pain are pathognomonic for testicular torsion, a surgical emergency.
questions.hint: The testicle is twisted and pulled upward.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common complication associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?
questions.explanation: BPH constricts the urethra, leading to incomplete emptying and eventually acute or chronic urinary retention.
questions.hint: If the prostate squeezes the urethra too tight, urine cannot get out.

questions.question: A patient presents with sudden-onset severe lower abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and inability to pass urine. On physical examination, there is suprapubic tenderness and a palpable bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A palpable, tender bladder with the inability to void confirms acute urinary retention.
questions.hint: The bladder is full but cannot empty.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common complication associated with prostatectomy for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?
questions.explanation: Retrograde ejaculation (semen entering the bladder instead of exiting) is a very common side effect of Transurethral Resection of the Prostate (TURP).
questions.hint: The bladder neck muscle is altered, causing fluid to go backward during climax.

questions.question: A patient with chronic kidney disease presents with fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, peripheral edema, and hypertension. Laboratory findings reveal elevated serum creatinine and urea levels, metabolic acidosis, and hyperkalemia. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

options.text: Initiation of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor therapy

questions.explanation: The patient meets multiple urgent criteria for dialysis (AEIOU): Acidosis, Electrolyte abnormality (Hyperkalemia), Overload (Edema/Dyspnea), and Uremia.
questions.hint: When meds aren't enough to handle potassium, acid, and fluid overload, you need a machine.

questions.question: A patient with renal failure presents with confusion, seizures, asterixis, and a sweet odor to the breath. Laboratory findings reveal severe metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Uremic encephalopathy occurs when high levels of toxins (BUN) affect the brain, causing confusion, seizures, and a characteristic breath odor (uremic fetor).
questions.hint: Brain dysfunction caused by kidney failure toxins.

questions.question: A patient presents with gross hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable abdominal mass. Imaging reveals a large heterogeneous renal mass with areas of necrosis and calcifications. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.explanation: This describes the classic presentation of Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC).
questions.hint: The most common type of kidney cancer.

questions.question: A patient presents with fever, chills, and costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals pyuria and bacteriuria. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.explanation: Fever + CVA Tenderness + UTI findings distinguishes Pyelonephritis (Upper UTI) from Cystitis (Lower UTI).
questions.hint: Infection that has ascended to the kidney itself.

richContent.content:
SymptomCystitisPyelonephritis
FeverRareCommon
PainSuprapubicFlank/CVA

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is characterized by an imbalance between bone resorption and formation, resulting in bone thinning and increased risk of fractures?
questions.explanation: Osteoporosis is defined by low bone mass and deterioration of bone tissue, leading to fragility.
questions.hint: Means 'porous bone'.

questions.question: A patient presents with urinary urgency, frequency, and nocturia. On physical examination, there is enlargement of the prostate gland with a smooth, firm consistency on digital rectal examination (DRE). Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.explanation: A smooth, firm, and enlarged prostate is characteristic of BPH. Prostate cancer typically feels nodular, hard, or irregular.
questions.hint: Benign enlargement feels smooth; cancer feels rocky.

questions.question: A patient with chronic kidney disease presents with periorbital edema, hypertension, and proteinuria. Laboratory findings reveal elevated serum creatinine and urea levels, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The question describes a patient 'with chronic kidney disease' presenting with classic uremic symptoms and CKD progression.
questions.hint: The question text itself gives you the diagnosis in the first sentence.

questions.question: A patient presents with scrotal pain, swelling, and erythema. On physical examination, there is a tender, fluctuant mass in the scrotum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Epididymitis presents with inflammation (pain, swelling, erythema). A 'fluctuant' mass suggests fluid or abscess, commonly associated with severe infection. Among the options, Epididymitis is the inflammatory condition.
questions.hint: Infection/inflammation of the tube at the back of the testicle.

questions.question: Which of the following medications is commonly used for the management of overactive bladder (OAB) symptoms such as urinary urgency and frequency?
questions.explanation: Oxybutynin is an anticholinergic medication that relaxes the bladder muscle (detrusor) to treat overactivity.
questions.hint: An anticholinergic drug used to relax the bladder.

questions.question: Which of the following laboratory findings is characteristic of nephrotic syndrome?
questions.explanation: Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by massive proteinuria (>3.5g/day), which leads to low serum albumin (Hypoalbuminemia) and edema.
questions.hint: Losing massive amounts of protein in the urine leads to low protein in the blood.

richContent.content:
Nephrotic SyndromeNephritic Syndrome
Massive ProteinuriaMild Proteinuria
HypoalbuminemiaHematuria (RBC casts)
EdemaHypertension

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is characterized by inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys, leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and hypertension?
questions.explanation: Acute glomerulonephritis (Nephritic Syndrome) is characterized by inflammation leading to Hematuria, Hypertension, and mild proteinuria.
questions.hint: Think 'Nephritic' = Inflammatory = Blood.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is characterized by the formation of calcium oxalate or calcium phosphate stones within the renal collecting system?
questions.explanation: Nephrolithiasis is the medical term for kidney stones (renal calculi).
questions.hint: The medical term for kidney stones.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is characterized by inflammation of the prostate gland, typically presenting with dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, and perineal or pelvic pain?
questions.explanation: Prostatitis is the inflammation/infection of the prostate gland, often causing pelvic pain and urinary symptoms.
questions.hint: Inflammation (-itis) of the prostate.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is characterized by an abnormal enlargement of the prostate gland, leading to lower urinary tract symptoms such as urinary hesitancy, weak urinary stream, and incomplete bladder emptying?
questions.explanation: BPH is the non-cancerous enlargement of the prostate that obstructs urine flow.
questions.hint: Benign enlargement of the prostate.

questions.question: A patient presents with fever, chills, and costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals pyuria and bacteriuria. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.explanation: Fever and Costovertebral Angle (CVA) tenderness are the hallmarks of kidney infection (pyelonephritis), distinguishing it from a bladder infection.
questions.hint: The infection has moved up from the bladder to the kidneys.
